[[Vaballathus]]
[[Hairan II]] |full name = Septimius Udaynath | father =Hairan |house= |birth_date = c. 220 |birth_place = Palmyra, [[Syria]] |death_date = {{death year and age|df=yes|267|220}} |death_place = [[Heraclea Pontica]] or [[Homs]] |}} '''Septimius Udaynath''', Latinized as '''Odaenathus''' '''('''[[Palmyrene dialect|Palmyrene]]: [[File:Dynt.png|55x55px]] ({{transl|syc|''''Dynt'''}}), spelled '''Oḏainaṯ'''; {{lang-ar|'''أذينة'''}} ({{transl|ar|'''Udhaynah'''}}); c.220–267''')''', was the founder king ([[Malik|Mlk]]) of the Palmyrene Kingdom centered at [[Palmyra]], [[Syria]]. He lifted his city from the position of a regional center subordinate to Rome into the supreme power in the [[Syria (region)#Syria 2|East]]. Odaenathus was born into an aristocratic Palmyrene family who had received [[Roman citizenship]] in the 190s under the [[Severan dynasty]]. He was the son of Hairan the descendant of Nasor. The circumstances surrounding his rise are ambiguous; he became the lord (Ras) of the city, a position created for him, as early as the 240s and by 258, he was styled a ''[[consularis]]'', indicating a high status in the [[Roman Empire]]. The defeat and captivity of emperor [[Valerian (emperor)|Valerian]] at the hands of the Persian [[Sassanian]] monarch [[Shapur I]] in 260 left the eastern Roman provinces largely at the mercy of the [[Persia]]ns. Odaenathus stayed on the side of Rome; assuming the title of king, he led the [[Palmyrene army]] and fell upon the Persians before they could cross the [[Euphrates]] to the eastern bank, and inflicted upon them a considerable defeat. Then, Odaenathus took the side of emperor [[Gallienus]], the son and successor of Valerian, who was facing the usurpation of [[Fulvius Macrianus]]. The rebel declared his sons emperors, leaving one in [[Syria (Roman province)|Syria]] and taking the other with him to Europe. Odaenathus attacked the remaining usurper and quelled the rebellion. He was rewarded many exceptional titles by the emperor who formalized his self-established position in the East. In reality, the emperor could have done little but to accept the declared nominal loyalty of Odaenathus. In a series of rapid and successful campaigns starting in 262, he crossed the Euphrates and recovered [[Carrhae]] and [[Nisibis]]. He then took the offensive to the heartland of Persia, and arrived at the walls of its capital [[Ctesiphon]]. The city withstood the short siege but Odaenathus reclaimed the entirety of Roman lands occupied by the Persians since the beginning of their [[Siege of Nisibis (252)|invasions in 252]]. Odaenathus celebrated his victories and declared himself [[King of Kings]], crowning his son [[Hairan I]] as co-king. By 263, Odaenathus was in effective control of the [[Levant]], [[Upper Mesopotamia|Mesopotamia]] and [[Anatolia]]'s eastern region. Odaenathus observed all due formalities towards the emperor, but in practice ruled as an independent monarch. In 266, the king launched a second invasion of Persia but had to abandon the campaign and head north to [[Bithynia]] to repel the attacks of Germanic riders besieging the city of [[Heraclea Pontica]]. He was assassinated in 267 during or immediately after the Anatolian campaign, together with Hairan. The identities of the perpetrator or the instigator are unknown and many stories, accusations and speculations exist in ancient sources. He was succeeded by his son [[Vaballathus]] under the regency of his widow [[Zenobia]], who used the power established by Odaenathus to forge the [[Palmyrene Empire]] in 270. ==Family and name== [[File:Palmyra inscription.png|thumb|alt=Ruined building|The stone block from Odaenathus' tomb recording his genealogy]] [[File:Cult relief of the Gad (Fortune) of Dura, from the Temple of the Gadde.jpg|thumb|Relief from [[Dura-Europos]] depicting the god "[[Gad (deity)|Gad]]" of Dura (center), king [[Seleucus I Nicator]] (right) and Hairan son of Maliko son of Nasor (left).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=fsoipziOWpYC&pg=PA225|title=Images and Monuments of Near Eastern Dynasts, 100 BC - AD 100|author=Andreas J. M. Kropp|page= 225|year= 2013}}]] The origin of the family is [[Aramean]],{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tQHQBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT113|title=Ezra and the Law in History and Tradition|author= Lisbeth S. Fried|page= 113|year= 2014}} while the king himself appears to be of mixed Aramean and [[Arab]] descent;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=A7joBeDsajcC&pg=PA130|title=Histories of the Middle East: Studies in Middle Eastern Society, Economy and Law in Honor of A.L. Udovitch|author1=Roxani Eleni Margariti |author2=Adam Sabra |author3=Petra Sijpesteijn |page= 130|year= 2010}} his name is Arabic, while the names of his ancestors (father Hairan and great grandfather Nasor) are [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=8kLFfE1qPhIC&pg=PA77|title=Palmyra and Its Empire: Zenobia's Revolt Against Rome|author= Richard Stoneman|page= 77|year= 1994}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=oZcr7SzzVYYC&pg=PA195|title=A Journey to Palmyra: Collected Essays to Remember Delbert R. Hillers|author1=Delbert R. Hillers |author2=Eleonora Cussini |page= 195|year= 2005}} [[Zosimus]] asserted that Odaenathus descended from "illustrious forebears", but the position of the family in Palmyra is debated; it was probably part of the wealthy mercantile class.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=73-JAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA77|title=Rome in the East: The Transformation of an Empire|author= Warwick Ball|page= 77|year= 2002}} Alternatively, the family may have belonged to the tribal leadership who amassed a fortune as landowners and patrons of the Palmyrene caravans.{{#tag:ref|Palmyrene caravan patrons owned the land on which the caravan animals were raised, providing animals and guards for the merchants who led the caravans.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6QPWXrCCzBIC&pg=PA159#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Transnationalism in Ancient and Medieval Societies: The Role of Cross-Border Trade and Travel |author=Michael C. Howard |page=159 |year=2012}}|group=note}} In [[Dura-Europos]], a relief dated to 159 was commissioned by Hairan son of Maliko son of Nasor; this Hairan might have been the head of the Palmyrene trade colony in Dura-Europos and probably belonged to the same family of Odaenathus.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=h5cMho6zFckC&pg=PA154|title=Roman Palmyra: Identity, Community, and State Formation|author= Andrew M. Smith II|page= 154|year= 2013}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=69YUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA67|title=Cults and Beliefs at Edessa|author= H. J. W. Drijvers|page= 67|year= 1980}} "Nasor" father of Maliko mentioned in the Dura-Europos inscription could therefore be Odaenathus' great-great-great grandfather.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?hl=nl&id=fRYVAQAAIAAJ&dq|title=The Excavations at Dura-Europos: Preliminary Report of the Work|author1=M. I. Rostovtzeff |author2=F. E. Brown |author3=C. B. Welles |page= 257|year= 1933}} "Odaenathus" is the Roman version of the king's name; he was born Septimius Udaynath c. 220.{{#tag:ref|The 220 date is proposed by [[Michael Gawlikowski]], head of the Polish archaeological expedition in Palmyra; [[Ernest Will]], however, maintains that the king was born c. 200.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=aqvpBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA348|title=Die Zeit der Soldatenkaiser: Krise und Transformation des Römischen Reiches im 3. Jahrhundert n. Chr. (235-284)|author=Klaus-Peter Johne|page= 348|language= de|year= 2008}}|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=41-MAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA286#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Ancient Syria: A Three Thousand Year History|author=Trevor Bryce|page= 286|year= 2014}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=LbqF8z2bq3sC&pg=PA1048|title=The Classical Tradition|author1=Anthony Grafton |author2=Glenn W Most |author3=Salvatore Settis |page= 1048|year= 2010}} Written in Palmyrene as Sptmyws 'Dynt;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3gGKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA61|title= The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars AD 226-363: A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 77|year= 2002}} "Udaynath" is the king's personal name,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=73-JAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA6|title=Rome in the East: The Transformation of an Empire|author=Warwick Ball|page= 6|year= 2002}} an [[Arabic language|Arabic]] one that means "little ear".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=nYvrAAAAMAAJ&q|title=The Enemies of Rome: From Hannibal to Attila the Hun|author=Philip Matyszak|page= 246|year= 2009}} "Septimius" was the family's [[Roman naming conventions#Nomen|gentilicium]] (surname) adopted as an expression of loyalty to the Roman [[Severan dynasty]],{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BEvEV9OVzacC&pg=PA296|title=Byzantium and the Arabs in the Sixth Century, Volume 1|author= Irfan Shahîd|page= 296|year= 1995}} whose emperor [[Septimius Severus]] granted the family [[Roman citizenship]] in the late second century.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=coYrAQAAIAAJ&q|title=Lives of the Romans|author1=Philip Matyszak |author2=Joanne Berry |page= 244|year= 2008}} ===Odaenathus I=== In the [[Temple of Bel]] at Palmyra, a stone block with a sepulchral inscription was found mentioning the building of a tomb and recording the genealogy of the builder: Odaenathus son of Hairan son of Wahb Allat son of Nasor.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=Q-mEnEfnVNUC&pg=PA166|title=Damascus and Palmyra: a journey to the East, Volume 2|author=Charles Greenstreet Addison|page= 166|year= 1838}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=dz3d7ymB1f4C&pg=PA68|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars (AD 226-363): A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 68|year= 1993}} Traditional scholarship believed the builder to be an ancestor of the king and he was given the designation "Odaenathus I".{{#tag:ref|This assumption was facilitated by a passage in the work of [[:de:Anonymus post Dionem|Anonymus post Dionem]] which speaks about a younger Odaenathus asking the Roman emperor to punish his official Rufinus for the latter's role in assassinating an elder Odaenathus.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=dz3d7ymB1f4C&pg=PA369|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars (AD 226-363): A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 369|year= 1993}} For information see [[Odaenathus#Assassination theories|Assassination of Odaenathus theories: Roman conspiracy]].|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=MNSyT_PuYVMC&pg=PA512#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Cambridge Ancient History: Volume 12, The Crisis of Empire, AD 193-337|author1=Alan Bowman |author2=Peter Garnsey |author3=Averil Cameron |page= 512|year= 2005}} In an inscription dated to 251, the name of the "Ras" (lord) of Palmyra Hairan son of Odaenathus is written,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=dz3d7ymB1f4C&pg=PA69|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars (AD 226-363): A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 69|year= 1993}} and he was thought to be the son of Odaenathus I. Prior to the 1980s, the earliest known inscription attesting king Odaenathus was dated to 257, leading traditional scholarship to believe that Hairan Ras of Palmyra is the father of the king and that Odaenathus I was his grandfather.{{#tag:ref|[[William Waddington#Archaeological research|William Waddington]] considered king Odaenathus the son of Ras Hairan while [[Theodor Mommsen]] considered the latter an older brother of the king.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=i4VLAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|title=Studies in the History of the Roman Province of Syria|author= Gustave Adolphus Harrer|page= 59|year= 1915}}|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=kJ2JAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA29|title=Aurelian and the Third Century|author=Alaric Watson|page= 29|year= 2004}} However, an inscription published in 1985 by archaeologist [[Michael Gawlikowski]] and dated to 252 mentions king Odaenathus as a "Ras" and records the same genealogy found in the sepulchral inscription confirming the name of king Odaenathus' grandfather as Wahb Allat.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=8kLFfE1qPhIC&pg=PA78|title=Palmyra and Its Empire: Zenobia's Revolt Against Rome|author= Richard Stoneman|page= 78|year= 1994}} Therefor, it is certain that king Odaenathus is the builder of the tomb ruling out the existence of "Odaenathus I". Ras Hairan mentioned in the 251 inscription is identical with Odaenathus' elder son and co-ruler prince [[Hairan I]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=9y7nTpFcN3AC&pg=PA352|title=The Middle East Under Rome|author= [[Maurice Sartre]]|page= 352|year= 2005}} ==Rise== Palmyra was an autonomous city subordinate to [[Roman Empire|Rome]] and part of [[Phoenice (Roman province)|Syria Phoenice]] province.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DQgmOZlsEWcC&pg=PA27|title= Between Rome and Persia: The Middle Euphrates, Mesopotamia and Palmyra Under Roman Control|author= Peter Edwell|page= 27|year= 2007}} Odaenathus descended from an aristocratic family, albeit not a royal one as the city was ruled by a council and had no tradition of hereditary monarchy.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qQKIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA76#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Rome in the East: The Transformation of an Empire|author= Warwick Ball|page= 76|year= 2002}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DQgmOZlsEWcC&pg=PA34|title=Between Rome and Persia: The Middle Euphrates, Mesopotamia and Palmyra Under Roman Control|author= Peter Edwell|page= 34|year= 2007}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=muVoB0O_XXMC&pg=PT62#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Fall Of The West: The Death Of The Roman Superpower|author= Adrian Goldsworthy|page= 62|year= 2009}} Bilingual inscriptions from Palmyra record the title of the Palmyrene ruler as "Ras" in [[Palmyrene dialect|Palmyrene]] and [[Exarch]]os in [[Greek language|Greek]], meaning the "Lord of Palmyra".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=E5yCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA209|title=Rome's Eastern Trade: International Commerce and Imperial Policy 31 BC - AD 305|author= Gary K. Young|page= 209|year= 2003}} The title was created for Odaenathus,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecfiAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA45#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 45|year= 2008}} and was not a usual title in the [[Roman Empire]] or a part of the traditional Palmyrene governance institutions;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecfiAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA44#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 44|year= 2008}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6rLDy6qqi0UC&pg=PA272|title=Ancient Rome: A Military and Political History|author=Christopher S. Mackay|page= 272|year= 2004}} whether it indicated a military or a priestly position is unknown,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h5cMho6zFckC&pg=PA131#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Roman Palmyra: Identity, Community, and State Formation|author= Andrew M. Smith II|page= 131|year= 2013}} but the military role is more likely.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uZqQjkb07g8C&pg=PA224|title= Power and Status in the Roman Empire, AD 193-284|author= Inge Mennen|page= 224|year= 2011}} The rise of the aggressive [[Sasanian Empire]] in 224 and the Iranian incursions which affected Palmyrene trade,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC&pg=PA43|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 43|year= 2008}} combined with the weakness of the Roman empire, were probably the reasons behind the Palmyrene council's decision to elect a lord for the city in order for him to lead a strengthened army.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=g4ZmqsyC5kEC&pg=PA160|title= A Companion to the Roman Empire|author= David S. Potter|page= 160|year= 2009}} The "Ras" title enabled the bearer to tackle the difficult situation that arose due to the Sasanian insurgencies; the supreme authority of the Ras probably made him the supreme civil and military commander with authority over the entire [[Palmyrene army]], which was previously decentralized and led by different generals. ===Ras of Palmyra=== An undated inscription refers to Odaenathus as a Ras and records the gift of a [[throne]] to him by a Palmyrene citizen named "Ogeilu son of Maqqai Haddudan Hadda", which confirms the supreme character of Odaenathus' title. The earliest known inscriptions mentioning the title are dated to October 251 and April 252; the 251 inscription refer to Odaenathus' eldest son Hairan I as Ras while the 252 inscription mention Odaenathus with that title.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=kJ2JAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA30|title= Aurelian and the Third Century|author= Alaric Watson|page= 30|year= 2004}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=E5yCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA210|title= Rome's Eastern Trade: International Commerce and Imperial Policy 31 BC - AD 305|author=Gary K. Young|page= 210|year= 2003}} Hairan I was apparently elevated to co-lordship status by his father. Although the written evidence for Odaenathus lordship dates to 251,{{#tag:ref|Although the first known inscription attesting Odaenathus' title date to 252, it is confirmed that he rose to the position at least one year earlier based on Hairan I's attestation as Ras in 251.|group=note}} it is possible that he acquired the title as early as the 240s; following the death of Roman emperor [[Gordian III]] in 244 during a campaign against Persia, the Palmyrenes might have elected Odaenathus to defend the city. [[File:DuraEuropos-TempleOfBel.jpg|thumb|The temple of [[Bel (mythology)|Bel]] belonging to the Palmyrene colony in Dura-Europos; destroyed by the Sassanians in 256.{{#tag:ref|There are two temples of Bel in Dura-Europos; the first was established by the Palmyrenes in the early first century outside the city wall in the necropolis and the second (depicted in this picture, also named "the temple of the Palmyrene gods") was administrated by Palmyrenes only in the third century.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=_LfXg2r6FT0C&pg=PA42|title=The Palmyrenes of Dura-Europos: A Study of Religious Interaction in Roman Syria|author=Lucinda Dirven|page= 42|year= 1999}}|group=note}}]] Odaenathus was described as [[Senate of the Roman Empire|Roman senator]] in the undated tomb inscription and Hairan I was mentioned with the same title in the 251 inscription.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC&pg=PA179|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 179|year= 2008}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=0TsSdzpN39MC&pg=PA402|title="Imitation Greeks": Being Syrian in the Greco-Roman World (175 BCE--275 CE).|author=Nathanael J. Andrade|page= 402|year= 2009}} Scholarly opinions vary on the exact date of Odaenathus' elevation to the position; Gawlikowski and [[Jean Starcky]] maintain that the senatorial rank predates the Ras elevation. [[Udo Hartmann]] concludes that Odaenathus first became a Ras in the 240s then a senator in 250. Another possibility is that the senatorial rank and lordship occurred simultaneously; Odaenathus was chosen as a Ras following Gordian's death, then after [[Philip the Arab]] concluded a peace with the Persians, the emperor ratified Odaenathus' lordship and admitted him to the senate to guarantee Palmyra's continuous subordination. As early as the 240s, Odaenathus inflated the Palmyrene army, recruiting the desert nomads and increasing the numbers of the Palmyrene heavy cavalry units ([[clibanarii]]).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA99|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 99|year= 2001|language= de}} [[Siege of Nisibis (252)|In 252]], Persian emperor [[Shapur I]] started a full-scale invasion of the Roman provinces in the east.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=IA-YlZqHv90C&pg=PA159|title=The Roman Near East, 31 B.C.-A.D. 337|author=Fergus Millar|page= 159|year= 1993}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DQgmOZlsEWcC&pg=PA185|title=Between Rome and Persia: The Middle Euphrates, Mesopotamia and Palmyra Under Roman Control|author=Peter Edwell|page= 185|year= 2007}} During the second campaign of the invasion, Shapur conquered [[Antioch]] and headed south where his advance was checked in 253 by [[Emesa]]'s priest king [[Uranius|Uranius Antoninus]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=4geGv5N8AUoC&pg=PA98|title=All Those Nations: Cultural Encounters Within and with the Near East : Studies Presented to Hans Drijvers at the Occasion of His Sixty-fifth Birthday by Colleagues and Students|author=Han J. W. Drijvers, H. L. Herman L. J. Vanstiphout, [[Wout van Bekkum|Wout Jacques van Bekkum]], G. J. H. van Gelder, Gerrit Jan Reinink|page= 98|year= 1999}} The events of 253 were mentioned in the works of the sixth century historian [[John Malalas]] who also mentioned a leader by the name "Enathus" inflicting a defeat upon the retreating Shapur near the [[Euphrates]]. "Enathus" is probably identical with Odaenathus,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC&pg=PA182|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 182|year= 2008}} and while Malalas' account indicate that Odaenathus defeated the Persians in 253,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=MG2hqcRDvJgC&pg=PA158|title=Rome and Persia in Late Antiquity: Neighbours and Rivals|author1=Beate Dignas |author2=Engelbert Winter |page= 158|year= 2007}} there is no proof that the Palmyrene leader engaged Shapur before 260 and Malalas' account seems to be confusing Odaenathus' future actions during 260 with the events of 253.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA100|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 100|year= 2001|language= de}} Shapur I destroyed the Palmyrene trade colonies all along the Euphrates (including the colonies at [[Anah]] in 253 and at [[Siege of Dura Europos (256)|Dura-Europos in 256]]);{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h5cMho6zFckC&pg=PA177#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Roman Palmyra: Identity, Community, and State Formation|author= Andrew M. Smith II|page= 177|year= 2013}} [[Peter the Patrician]] says that Odaenathus approached Shapur to negotiate Palmyrene interests but was rebuffed and the gifts sent to the Persians were thrown into the river.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA60|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 60|year= 2008}} The date for the attempted negotiations is debated; Some scholars including [[John F. Drinkwater]] set the event in 253 while others such as [[Alaric Watson]] set it in 256 following the destruction of Dura-Europos. ===Governor of Syria Phoenice=== Several inscriptions dating to the end of 257 or early 258 show Odaenathus bearing the title "''ὁ λαμπρότατος ὑπατικός''" (''[[Consularis|Clarissimus Consularis]]'');{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA47#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 47|year= 2008}} this could be a mere honoring or a sign that he was appointed as the [[Legatus]] of Phoenice.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=E5yCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA159|title= Rome's Eastern Trade: International Commerce and Imperial Policy 31 BC - AD 305|author=Gary K. Young|page= 159|year= 2003}} However, the title (''ὁ λαμπρότατος ὑπατικός'') was sometimes used in Syria to denote the provincial governor and [[William Waddington#Archaeological research|William Waddington]] proposed that Odaenathus was indeed the governor of Phoenice.{{#tag:ref|[[:de:Hermann Schiller|Hermann Schiller]] denied Odaenathus was a governor of Phoenice; the (''ὁ λαμπρότατος ὑπατικός'') title was also attested in Palmyra for different notables and it could have been an honorary title of high degree.|group=note}} Five of the inscriptions mentioning Odaenathus as consul are dated to the [[Seleucid era|Seleucid year]] 569 (258 AD) during which no governor for Phoenice is attested, which might indicate that this was Odaenathus' year of governorship.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA48#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 48|year= 2008}} In the city of [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]], Phoenice's capital, the lines "To Septimius Odaenathus, the most illustrious. The Septimian colony of Tyre" were found inscribed on a marble base;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tgCKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA77|title= The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars AD 226-363: A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 77|year= 2002}} the inscription is not dated and if it was set after 257 then it indicates that Odaenathus was appointed as the governor of the province. [[File:Bas relief nagsh-e-rostam al.jpg|thumb|Bas relief depicting the triumph of Shapur I over Valerian]] These speculations cannot be proven without doubt but as a governor, Odaenathus would have been the highest authority in the province and above any legionary commander and provincial officials; this would make him the commander of the Roman forces in the province. Whatever the case may be, starting from 258, Odaenathus strengthened his position and extended his political influence in the region. By 260, Odaenathus held the rank, credibility and power to pacify the Roman east following the [[Battle of Edessa]]. ===Edessa=== Faced with Shapur's third campaign,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=IA-YlZqHv90C&pg=PA166|title= The Roman Near East, 31 B.C.-A.D. 337|author= Fergus Millar|page= 166|year= 1993}} the Roman emperor [[Valerian (emperor)|Valerian]] marched against the Persian monarch but was defeated near Edessa in late spring 260 and taken as a prisoner.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=2fTcCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA167|title= Imperial Rome AD 193 to 284: The Critical Century|author=Clifford Ando|page= 167|year= 2012}} The Persian emperor then ravaged [[Cappadocia (Roman province)|Cappadocia]], [[Cilicia (Roman province)|Cilicia]] and claimed to have captured [[Antioch]], the metropolis of [[Syria (Roman province)|Syria]].{{#tag:ref|There is no proof that Shapur entered the central areas of northern Syria; he seems to have moved directly west deep into Cilicia.|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=MG2hqcRDvJgC&pg=PA23|title= Rome and Persia in Late Antiquity: Neighbours and Rivals|author1=Beate Dignas |author2=Engelbert Winter |page= 23|year= 2007}} Taking advantage of the situation, [[Fulvius Macrianus]], the commander of the imperial treasury, declared his sons [[Quietus]] and [[Macrianus Minor]] as joint emperors in August 260 opposing Valerian's son [[Gallienus]].{{#tag:ref|At first Fulvius Macrianus showed loyalty to Gallienus.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=MNSyT_PuYVMC&pg=PA44|title= The Cambridge Ancient History: Volume 12, The Crisis of Empire, AD 193-337|author1=Alan Bowman |author2=Peter Garnsey |author3=Averil Cameron |page= 44|year= 2005}}|group=note}} Fulvius Macrianus took Antioch as his center and organized the resistance against Shapur; he dispatched [[Balista]], his praetorian prefect, to [[Anatolia]]. Shapur was defeated in the region of [[Elaiussa Sebaste|Sebaste]] at [[Soli, Cilicia|Pompeiopolis]] prompting the Persians to evacuate Cilicia while Balista went back to Antioch.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=dz3d7ymB1f4C&pg=PA66|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars (AD 226-363): A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 66|year= 1993}} Balista's victory was only partial, as Shapur withdrew east of Cilicia where the marauding Persian units continued to occupy the area,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA58|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 58|year= 2008}} while a Persian force took advantage of Balista's return to Syria and headed further west in Anatolia. ==Reign== According to the [[Augustan History]], Odaenathus was declared king of Palmyra as soon as the news of the Roman defeat at Edessa reached the city.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MG2hqcRDvJgC&pg=PA159#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Rome and Persia in Late Antiquity: Neighbours and Rivals|author1=Beate Dignas |author2=Engelbert Winter |page= 159|year= 2007}} It is not known if Odaenathus contacted Fulvius Macrianus and there is no evidence that he took orders from him.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 59|year= 2008}} ===Early Persian war and Syria=== Odaenathus assembled the Palmyrene army and Syrian peasants then marched north to meet the Persian emperor, who was back from Cilicia.{{#tag:ref|No evidence exists, but Odaenathus might have had some Roman units in his ranks considering that he was fighting in the surroundings of Roman legionary bases; those troops might have been loyal to Gallienus and thus chose to join Odaenathus. Whether Roman soldiers fought under Odaenathus or not is a matter of speculation.|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=WzOGycVVQLEC&pg=PA398|title= Coinage and History of the Roman Empire, C. 82 B.C.--A.D. 480: History, Volume 1|author=David L. Vagi|page= 397|year= 1999}} The Palmyrene monarch fell upon the retreating Shapur at a place between [[Samosata]] and [[Zeugma, Commagene|Zeugma]] west of the [[Euphrates]] in late summer 260.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=h5_tSnygvbIC&pg=PA148|title= A Global Chronology of Conflict: From the Ancient World to the Modern Middle East: From the Ancient World to the Modern Middle East|author=Spencer C. Tucker|page= 148|year= 2009}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA144|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 144|year= 2001|language= de}} Odaenathus defeated the Persians, expelling Shapur from the province of Syria. However, the Sassanians kept the regions east of the Euphrates. In the beginning of 261, Fulvius Macrianus headed to Europe accompanied by Macrianus Minor leaving Quietus and Balista in Emesa. Odaenathus' whereabouts during this episode are not clear; he could have distributed the army in garrisons along the frontier or might have brought it back to his capital. The Palmyrene monarch seems to have waited until the situation clear, declaring loyalty neither to Fulvius Macrianus nor to Gallienus. In the spring of 261, Fulvius Macrianus arrived in the [[Balkans]] but was defeated and killed along with Macrianus Minor; Odaenathus then marched on Emesa where Quietus and Balista were staying. The Emesans killed Quietus as Odaenathus approached the city, while Balista was captured and executed by the king in autumn 261.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA145|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 145|year= 2001|language= de}} ====Ruler of the East==== The elimination of the usurpers left Odaenathus as the most powerful leader in the Roman east; he was granted many titles by the emperor but those honors are debated among scholars:{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=41-MAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA290|title=Ancient Syria: A Three Thousand Year History|author= Trevor Bryce|page= 290|year= 2014}} *''[[Dux]] Romanorum'' (commander of the Romans): was probably given to Odaenathus to recognize his position as the commander in chief of the forces in the east against the Persians; it was inherited by Odaenathus' son and successor [[Vaballathus]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=41-MAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA291|title=Ancient Syria: A Three Thousand Year History|author= Trevor Bryce|page= 291|year= 2014}} [[File:Odaenathus dedication.png|thumb|Copy of the posthumous dedication to Odaenathus attesting him as corrector written in Latin alphabet. The actual inscription is written in [[Palmyrene alphabet]] ]] *''[[Corrector]] totius orientis'' (commander of the entire East): it is generally accepted by modern scholars that he bore this title.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC&pg=PA67|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 67|year= 2008}} The corrector had an overall command of the Roman armies and authority over the Roman provincial governors in the designated region.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=E5yCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA215|title=Rome's Eastern Trade: International Commerce and Imperial Policy 31 BC - AD 305|author=Gary K. Young|page= 215|year= 2003}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=muVoB0O_XXMC&pg=PT61#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Fall Of The West: The Death Of The Roman Superpower|author= Adrian Goldsworthy|page= 61|year= 2009}} There are no known attestations of the title during Odaenathus' lifetime. Evidences for the king bearing the title are two inscriptions in [[Palmyrene dialect]]; one posthumous dedication describing him as ''MTQNNʿ'' of the East (derived from the [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] root ''TQN'', meaning to set in order), and the other describing his heir Vaballathus with the same title albeit using the word ''PNRTTʿ'' instead of ''MTQNNʿ''.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC&pg=PA68|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 68|year= 2008}} :However, the sort of authority accorded by this position is widely discussed. The problem arise from the word ''MTQNNʿ''; its exact meaning is debated. The word is translated to [[Latin language|Latin]] as corrector but restitutor is another possible translation; the latter title was an honorary one meant to praise the bearer for driving enemies out of Roman territories. However, the inscription of Vaballathus is clearer as the word ''PNRTTʿ'' is not a Palmyrene word but a direct Palmyrene translation of the Greek term ''Epanorthotes'' which is usually an equivalent to corrector. :According to [[David Potter (historian)|David Potter]], Vaballathus inherited his father's exact titles. Hartmann points that there have been cases where a Greek word was translated directly to Palmyrene and a Palmyrene equivalent was also used to mean the same thing. The dedication to Odaenathus would be the using of a Palmyrene equivalent, while the inscription of Vaballathus would be the direct translation. Despite all the arguments, it cannot be certain without doubt that Odaenathus was a corrector. *''[[Imperator]] totius orientis'' (emperor of the entire East): only the Augustan History claims that Odaenathus was conferred with this title, and also goes so far as to claim that he was made an [[Augustus (honorific)|Augustus]] (co-emperor) following his defeat of the Persians. Both claims are dismissed by scholars. Odaenathus seems to have been acclaimed as Imperator by his troops which is a salutation reserved for the Roman emperor; this acclamation might explain the erroneous reports of the Augustan History.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=kJ2JAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA32|title=Aurelian and the Third Century|author= Alaric Watson|page= 32|year= 2004}} Regardless of the titles, Odaenathus controlled the Roman East with the approval of Gallienus who could do little but to formalize Odaenathus self achieved status and settle for his formal loyalty.{{#tag:ref|The Roman East traditionally included all the Roman lands in Asia east of the [[Bosphorus]].|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=nG-S-X_uI6EC&pg=PA137|title=Crises and the Roman Empire: Proceedings of the Seventh Workshop of the International Network Impact of Empire, Nijmegen, June 20-24, 2006|author= Impact of Empire (Organització). Workshop|page= 137|year= 2007}} [[Palmyra#Autonomous Palmyrene region|Palmyra]] itself, although officially still part of the Roman empire, became a de facto allied state to Rome instead of a provincial city. Outside of Palmyra, Odaenathus' authority extended from the [[Pontus (region)|Pontic coast]] in the north to [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] in the south.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=MG2hqcRDvJgC&pg=PA160|title=Rome and Persia in Late Antiquity: Neighbours and Rivals|author1=Beate Dignas |author2=Engelbert Winter |page= 160|year= 2007}} This area included the Roman provinces of [[Syria (Roman province)|Syria]], Phoenice, [[Syria Palaestina|Palaestina]], [[Arabia Petraea|Arabia]], [[Anatolia]]'s eastern regions and later (following the campaign of 262) [[Osroene (Roman province)|Osroene]] and [[Mesopotamia (Roman province)|Mesopotamia]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=z10-Xz9Kno4C&pg=PA333|title=A Psychoanalytic History of the Jews|author=Avner Falk|page= 333|year= 1996}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=7-jUAMmMS5cC&pg=PA35|title=The Policy of the Emperor Gallienus|author= Lukas De Blois|page= 35|year= 1976}} ====First Persian campaign 262==== [[File:Odaenathus the Victorious.png|thumb|Mosaic of the tiger; it represent Odaenathus' victory over the Persians who are depicted as tigers.]] Perhaps driven by the will to take revenge for the destruction of Palmyrene trade centers and discourage Shapur from initiating future attacks, Odaenathus launched an invasion against the Persians.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecfiAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA70#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 70|year= 2008}} In the spring of 262, the king marched north into the occupied Roman province of Mesopotamia, driving out the Persian garrisons and freeing [[Edessa]] and [[Carrhae]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA173|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 173|language= de|year= 2001}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA168|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 168|language= de|year= 2001}} The first onslaught was aimed at [[Nisibis]], which Odaenathus regained but sacked since the inhabitants were sympathetic toward the Persian occupation. The Palmyrene monarch destroyed the Jewish city of [[Nehardea]], 45 km west of the Persian capital [[Ctesiphon]],{{#tag:ref|[[Lukas De Blois]] propose that Odaenathus actually destroyed Nehardea in 259 in support of Valerian.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=7-jUAMmMS5cC&pg=PA2|title=The Policy of the Emperor Gallienus|author= Lukas De Blois|page= 2|year= 1976}} In the work of [[Sherira Gaon]] named "Iggeret Rav Sherira Gaon", the destruction date is given as 570 (Seleucid), corresponding to 259 AD.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tgCKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA70|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars AD 226-363: A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 70|year= 2002}} However, [[Jacob Neusner]] believes that the right date is 262 or 263.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tgCKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA370|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars AD 226-363: A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 370|year= 2002}}|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA169|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 169|language= de|year= 2001}} as he deemed the [[Jews]] of Mesopotamia loyal to Shapur.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LLCXomFNU3cC&pg=PA151#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=HISTORY OF THE JEWS From the Roman Empire to the Early Medieval Period|author= Simon Dubnov|page= 151|year= 1968}} By late 262 or early 263, Odaenathus stood at the walls of the Persian capital.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA172|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 172|language= de|year= 2001}} The exact route taken by Odaenathus from Palmyra to Ctesiphon remains uncertain; it is probably similar to the route emperor [[Julian (emperor)#Into enemy territory|Julian]] took in 363 during his campaign against Persia.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA171|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 171|language= de|year= 2001}} Using this route, Odaenathus would have crossed the Euphrates at Zeugma then moved east to Edessa followed by Carrhae then Nisibis; here, he would have descended south along the [[Khabur River]] to the Euphrates valley and marched alongside the river's left bank to Nehardea. After taking the city, he penetrated the Sassanian province of [[Asōristān]] and marched along the royal canal [[Geography of Mesopotamia#Perennial irrigation|Naarmalcha]] towards the [[Tigris]] where the Persian capital stood. Once at Ctesiphon, Odaenathus immediately began [[Battle of Ctesiphon (263)|the siege]] of the well-fortified winter residence of the Persian kings; severe damage was inflicted upon the surrounding areas due to the battles with Persian troops. The city held its ground and the logistical problems of fighting in enemy's land probably prompted the Palmyrenes to lift the siege. Odaenathus headed north along the Euphrates carrying with him numerous prisoners and booty. The invasion resulted in the full restoration of the Roman lands ([[Osroene (Roman province)|Osroene]] and Mesopotamia provinces) occupied by Shapur since the beginning of his invasions in 252.{{#tag:ref|Contrary to the account of the Augustan History, there is no proof that Odaenathus occupied [[Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)|Armenia]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA174|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 174|language= de|year= 2001}}|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7-jUAMmMS5cC&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Policy of the Emperor Gallienus|author= Lukas De Blois|page= 3|year= 1976}} However, Dura-Europus and other Palmyrene posts south of [[Circesium]], such as Anah, were not rebuilt. Odaenathus sent the captives to Rome and by the end of 263, Gallienus added ''Persicus Maximus'' ("The great victor in Persia") to his titles and held a [[Roman triumph|triumph]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 71|year= 2008}} ===King of Kings=== In 263, after his return, Odaenathus assumed the title [[King of Kings]] of the East (Mlk Mlk),{{#tag:ref|Odaenathus' title as it appears in Palmyrene inscriptions was King of Kings and corrector of the East.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=YJPn3-rRjC0C&pg=PA60|title=Roman Syria and the Near East|author= Kevin Butcher|page= 60|year= 2003}}|group=note}} and headed to [[Antioch]], the traditional capital of Syria, where he crowned his son [[Hairan I]] as co-King of Kings.{{#tag:ref|'''1-''' The evidence for crowning Hairan I is a dedication found inscribed on a statue base from Palmyra which is undated. However, the dedication was made by [[Septimius Worod]] as the duumviri of Palmyra, an office occupied by Worod between 263 and 264. Hence, the coronation took place c. 263.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA178|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 178|language= de|year= 2001}}
'''2-''' An undated inscription, written in Greek and difficult to decipher, found on a stone reused in the Palmyrene [[Camp of Diocletian]], address Odaenathus as King of Kings (Rex Regum) and was probably set during his reign. However, firmly dated inscriptions attesting Odaenathus with the title are made after his death including one that was set in 271. Although undisputed evidence for the use of the title by Odaenathus during his lifetime is lacking, Hairan I, his son who died with him,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=oZcr7SzzVYYC&pg=PA198|title=A Journey to Palmyra: Collected Essays to Remember Delbert R. Hillers|author1=Delbert R. Hillers |author2=Eleonora Cussini |page= 198|year= 2005}} is directly attested as "King of Kings" during his lifetime, and it is highly unlikely that Odaenathus was simply a king while his son was the King of Kings.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecfiAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 72|year= 2008}}|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA176|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 176|language= de|year= 2001}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=y6IaBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA333|title=Syrian Identity in the Greco-Roman World|author=Nathanael J. Andrade|page= 333|year= 2013}} The title was a symbol of legitimacy in the East, starting with the [[Assyria]]ns then the [[Achaemenid]]s who used it to symbolize their supremacy over all other rulers and was adopted by the [[Parthian Empire|Parthian]] monarchs following their defeat of the Seleucids to legitimize their conquests.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA180|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 180|language= de|year= 2001}} The first Sassanian monarch [[Ardashir I]] adopted the title following his victory over the Parthians.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA181|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 181|language= de|year= 2001}} Odaenathus' son was crowned with a [[diadem]] and a [[tiara]]; the choice of the location was probably meant to express that the Palmyrene monarchs were now the successors of the [[Seleucid]] and Iranian rulers who controlled Syria and Mesopotamia in the past. ====Relation with Rome==== [[File:Hairan I.jpg|thumb|Hairan I wearing the Palmyrene crown]] In the Roman empire's hierarchical system, a vassal king usage of the King of Kings title did not indicate that he is a peer of the emperor or that the vassalage ties were cut.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA182|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 182|language= de|year= 2001}} The title was probably a challenge not to the Roman emperor but to Shapur I; Odaenathus was declaring that he, not the Persian monarch, was the legitimate King of Kings in the East.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=E5yCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA214|title=Rome's Eastern Trade: International Commerce and Imperial Policy 31 BC - AD 305|author= Gary K. Young|page= 214|year= 2003}} A lead token depicting Hairan I shows him wearing a crown shaped like that of the Parthian monarchs, so it must have been Odaenathus' crown;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=7HKFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA256|title=The Roman Empire at Bay, AD 180–395|author= David S Potter|page= 256|year= 2014}} this combination of title and imagery indicate that Odaenathus considered himself the rival of the Sassanians and the protector of the region against them.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=g4ZmqsyC5kEC&pg=PA162|title=A Companion to the Roman Empire|author= David S Potter|page= 162|year= 2009}} Odaenathus' intents are questioned by some historians such as Drinkwater who attribute the attempted negotiations with Shapur to Odaenathus' quest for power. However, in contrast to the norm of his period when powerful generals proclaimed themselves emperors, Odaenathus chose not to usurp Gallienus' throne,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=Dk2FAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA298|title=A History of Rome Under the Emperors|author= Theodor Mommsen|page= 298|year= 2005}} and minted no coins bearing his own image.{{#tag:ref|[[Hubertus Goltzius]] forged coins of Odaenathus in the 16th century;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=Jq6CJqB-qmAC&pg=PA63|title=Fasti Romani|author= Henry Fynes Clinton|page= 63|year= 2010}} according to [[Joseph Hilarius Eckhel]] "The coins of Odenathus are known only to Goltzius; and if any one will put faith in their existence, let him go to the fountain head (i.e. Goltzius)".{{cite book|url=http://www.forumancientcoins.com/Dictionary_Of_Roman_Coins/dictionaryByPage.asp?page=583|title=A Dictionary of Roman Coins, Republican and Imperial|author1=Seth William Stevenson |author2=Frederic William Madden |page= 583|year= 1889}} According to the Augustan History, Gallienus minted a coin in honor of Odaenathus where he was depicted leading the Persians captive; the existence of this coin is doubtful.|group=note}} The king had total control over his kingdom of Palmyra and effective control over the Roman East where his military authority was absolute.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=bpd3tBPN4v8C&pg=PA171|title=Imperial Rome AD 193 to 284: The Critical Century|author= Clifford Ando|page= 171|year= 2012}} Odaenathus respected Gallienus' privilege to appoint provincial governors, but dealt swiftly with opposition; the [[:de:Anonymus post Dionem|Anonymus post Dionem]] mention the story of [[Kyrinus]] (Quirinus), a Roman official, who showed dissatisfaction with Odaenathus' authority over the Persian frontier and was immediately executed by the king.{{#tag:ref|No information on the identity of Kyrinus exist;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA156|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 156|year= 2001}} it is possible that he is the same as Aurelius Quirinius, who is recorded as head of the financial administration of Egypt in 262.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=gE8RAQAAMAAJ&q|title=The Cambridge Ancient History, Volume 12|author1=S. A. Cook |author2=F. E. Adcock |author3=Martin Percival Charlesworth |author4=Norman Hepburn Baynes |page= 176|year= 1981}}|group=note}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tgCKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA76|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars AD 226-363: A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 76|year= 2002}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=NefgAAAAMAAJ&q|title=The Cambridge Ancient History, Volume 12|author1=Martin Percival Charlesworth |author2=Iorwerth Eiddon Stephen Edwards |author3=Norman Hepburn Baynes |author4=Charles Theodore Seltman |author5=John Boardman |author6=Frank William Walbank |page= 176|year= 1961}} In general, Odaenathus' actions were connected to his and Palmyra's interests only; his support of Gallienus and his Roman titles did not hide the Palmyrene base of his power and the local origin of his armies, as with his decision not to wait for the emperor to help in 260. Odaenathus' status seems to have been, as Watson put it, "something between powerful subject, independent vassal king and rival emperor". ====Administration==== [[File:Odaenathus Kingdom.png|thumb|Roman regions under the authority of Odaenathus (yellow) and the Palmyrene kingdom (green)]] Outside his kingdom, Odaenathus had an overall administrative and military authority over the provincial governors of the Roman eastern provinces.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA75|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 75|year= 2008}} Inside Palmyra, no Roman provincial official had any authority; the king filled the government with Palmyrene staffs.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=7HKFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA257|title=The Roman Empire at Bay, AD 180–395|author=David S Potter|page= 257|year= 2014}} In parallelism to the Iranian practice of making the government appear as a family enterprise, Odaenathus bestowed his own gentilicium (Septimius) upon his leading generals and officials such as [[Zabdas]], [[Septimius Zabbai|Zabbai]] and [[Septimius Worod|Worod]].{{#tag:ref|This gentilicium was exclusive to the family of Odaenathus prior to the 260s.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0fIq9wd3Z3oC&pg=PA209|title=Personalities of the Early Church|author= Everett Ferguson|page= 209|year= 1993}}|group=note}} The [[Palmyra#Government|Palmyrene constitutional institutions]] continued to function normally during Odaenathus' reign; he maintained the council and most civic establishments,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ttiIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT96#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Aurelian and the Third Century|author= Alaric Watson|page= 96|year= 2004}} permitting the election of [[Roman magistrate|magistrates]] until 264. When Odaenathus was on campaign, the kingdom was administered by a [[viceroy]],{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hJwa2cjamJMC&pg=PA104#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Provinces of the Roman Empire: From Caesar to Diocletian, Volume 2|author1=Theodor Mommsen |author2=William Purdie Dickson |author3=Francis Haverfield |page= 104|year= 1886}} Septimius Worod.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=KwsIAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA286|title=A text-book of North-Semitic inscriptions Moabite, Hebrew, Phoenician, Aramaic, Nabataean, Palmyrene, Jewish|author= George Albert Cooke|page= 286|year= 1923}} ====Second Persian campaign 266==== Sources are silent regarding the events following the first Persian campaign but the silence in itself is an indication of the peace that prevailed and that the Persians stopped being a threat to the Roman East.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=ecfiAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA73|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 73|year= 2008}} The evidence for the second campaign is meager; [[Zosimus]] is the only one to mention it specifically.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA76|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 76|year= 2008}} A passage in the [[Sibylline Oracles]] is interpreted by Hartmann as an indication of the second invasion.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=ecfiAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA183|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 183|year= 2008}} The campaign took place in 266 or 267 and was aimed directly at Ctesiphon; Odaenathus reached the walls of the Persian capital but had to cancel the siege and march north to face the influx of Germanic riders attacking Anatolia.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA216|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 216|year= 2001}} ====Anatolian campaign==== The Romans used the designation "[[Scythian]]" to denote many tribes regardless of ethnic origin and sometimes the term would be interchangeable with [[Goths]]; the tribes attacking Anatolia were probably the [[Heruli]] who built ships to cross the [[Black Sea]] in 267 and ravaged the coasts of [[Bithynia]]-[[Pontus]] besieging [[Heraclea Pontica]]. According to [[George Syncellus|Syncellus]], Odaenathus arrived at Anatolia with Hairan I and headed to Heraclea but the riders were already gone. They loaded the spoils onto their ships but many perished in a sea battle probably conducted by Odaenathus; another possibility is that they were shipwrecked. ==Assassination== Odaenathus was assassinated along with Hairan I in late 267; the date is debated and some scholars propose 266 or 268, but Vaballathus dated his first year of reign between August 267 and August 268, making late 267 the most probable date.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA77|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 77|year= 2008}} The assassination took place either in Anatolia,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA78|title= Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 78|year= 2008}} or in Syria while the king was returning to Palmyra;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WzOGycVVQLEC&pg=PA398#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Coinage and History of the Roman Empire, C. 82 B.C.--A.D. 480: History|author= David L. Vagi|page= 398|year= 2000}} there is no consensus on the manner, perpetrator or the motive behind the act. * According to Syncellus, Odaenathus was assassinated near Heraclea Pontica trying to quell a tribal incursion into Pontus; he gives the name of the assassin as another Odaenathus who may or may not have been a relative of the king. The assassin was killed by the king's bodyguard.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=dz3d7ymB1f4C&pg=PA82|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars (AD 226-363): A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 82|year= 1993}} Hartmann support the theory that Odaenathus was killed in Pontus. * Zosimus simply mention that Odaenathus was killed by conspirators near Emesa at a friend's birthday party without naming the killer.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA220|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 220|language= de|year= 2001}} [[Zonaras]] attributes the crime to a nephew of Odaenathus but does not give a name.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=7HKFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA259|title= The Roman Empire at Bay, AD 180–395|author= David S Potter|page= 259|year= 2014}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=hGuGAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT585|title= The Roman Empire at Bay, AD 180–395|author= David S Potter|page= 629|year= 2014}} * The Augustan History claims that a cousin of the king named [[Maeonius]] killed him,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=dz3d7ymB1f4C&pg=PA81|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars (AD 226-363): A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 81|year= 1993}} while the Anonymus post Dionem names the assassin as another Odaenathus. ===Burial=== [[File:Peristyl House Palmyra Syria.JPG|thumb|alt=Ruined building|The Funerary Temple no. 86 (The House Tomb)]] The stone block found in the Temple of Bel bearing Odaenathus' sepulchral inscription was brought from the tomb built by him; this shrine's location is unknown. At the western end of the [[Great Colonnade at Palmyra]], a shrine designated the "Funerary Temple no. 86" (also known as the House Tomb) is located.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oZcr7SzzVYYC&pg=PA55|title=A Journey to Palmyra: Collected Essays to Remember Delbert R. Hillers|author1=Delbert R. Hillers |author2=Eleonora Cussini |page=55|year=2005}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QNGyWSx8U34C&pg=PA103|title=Art and History Syria|author=Casa Editrice Bonechi|page=103|year= 2008}} Inside its chamber, steps lead down to a vault crypt which is now lost.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HuXAHGDSjNIC&pg=PA238#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Syria |author=Diana Darke |page=238|year= 2006}} This mausoleum might have belonged to the royal family, being the only tomb inside the city's walls.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8kLFfE1qPhIC&pg=PA67|title=Palmyra and Its Empire: Zenobia's Revolt Against Rome|author=Richard Stoneman|page=67|year= 1994}} ===Assassination theories=== * Roman conspiracy: [[John of Antioch (chronicler)|John Antiochenus]] accuse Gallienus of the assassination. An interesting passage in the work of the Anonymus post Dionem speaks of a certain "Rufinus" who orchestrated the assassination on his own initiative then explained his act to the emperor who condoned the crime. This story talks about Rufinus ordering the murder of an older Odaenathus out of fear that he would rebel, and has the younger Odaenathus complaining to the emperor.{{#tag:ref|This story gave rise to the now defunct assumption that Odaenathus I existed.|group=note}} Since the older Odaenathus (Odaenathus I) was proved to be a fictional character, the story was neglected by most scholars.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=8kLFfE1qPhIC&pg=PA108|title=Palmyra and Its Empire: Zenobia's Revolt Against Rome|author=Richard Stoneman|page= 108|year= 1994}} However, according to [[Theodor Mommsen]], younger Odaenathus is an oblique reference to Vaballathus;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tgCKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA371|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars (AD 226-363): A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 371|year= 1993}} Rufinus should be identified with [[Cocceius Rufinus]], the Roman governor of [[Arabia Petraea|Arabia]] between 261/262. The evidence for a Roman conspiracy is very weak and can not be confirmed. [[File:Maeonius.jpg|thumb|alt=Bearded relative of Odaenathus, wearing a metal hat|Maeonius as depicted in the ''[[Promptuarii Iconum Insigniorum]]'']] *Family feud: According to Zonaras, Odaenathus' nephew misbehaved during a lion hunt; he made the first attack and killed the animal to the dismay of the king. Odaenathus warned the nephew who ignored the warning and repeated the act twice causing the king to deprive him of his horse which is a great insult in the East.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=q8Z7AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA292|title=Ancient Syria: A Three Thousand Year History|author= Trevor Bryce|page= 292|year= 2014}} The nephew threatened Odaenathus and was put in chains as a result; Hairan I asked his father to forgive his cousin and his request was granted but as the king was drinking, the nephew approached him with a sword and killed him along with Hairan I. The bodyguard immediately executed the nephew. * Zenobia: the wife of Odaenathus was accused by the Augustan History of having formerly conspired with Maeonius, as Hairan I was her stepson and she could not accept that he was the heir to her husband instead of her own children. However, there is no suggestion in the Augustan History that Zenobia was involved in the event that saw her husband's murder; the act is attributed to Maeonius' degeneracy and jealousy. Those accounts by the Augustan History can be dismissed as fiction.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=kJ2JAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA58|title=Aurelian and the Third Century|author= Alaric Watson|page= 58|year= 2004}} The hints in modern scholarship that Zenobia had a hand in the assassination out of her desire to rule the empire and dismay with her husband's pro-Roman policy can be dismissed as there was no reversal of that policy during the first years following Odaenathus' death. * Persian agents or Palmyrene traitors: the possibility of a Persian involvement exists but the outcome of the assassination would not have served Shapur without establishing a pro-Persian monarch on the Palmyrene throne.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA79|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author= Pat Southern|page= 79|year= 2008}} Another possibility would be Palmyrenes dissatisfied with Odaenathus' reign and the changes of their city's governmental system. ==Personal life and succession== [[File:ZENOBIA - RIC V 2 - 80000750.jpg|thumb|Zenobia, Odaenathus' second wife]] Odaenathus was married twice; nothing is known about his first wife's name or fate.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA8|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 8|year= 2008}} [[Zenobia]] was the king's second wife whom he married in the late 250s when she was 17 or 18 years old.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA4|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 4|year= 2008}} The number of children Odaenathus had with his first wife is unknown and only one is attested: *[[Hairan I]]: the name appears on a 251 inscription from Palmyra describing him as Ras implying that he was already an adult by then. In the Augustan History, Odaenathus' eldest son is named Herod; the inscription at Palmyra dating to 263 celebrating Hairan's coronation mentions him with the name Herodianus. It is possible that Hairan of the 251 inscription is not the same as Herodianus of the 263, but this is contested by Hartmann who conclude that the reason for the difference in the spelling is due to the language used in the inscription (Herodianus being the Greek version), meaning that Odaenathus' eldest son and co-king is Hairan Herodianus.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA9|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 9|year= 2008}} [[File:Antoninian Vaballathus Augustus.jpg|thumb|Vaballathus, Odaenathus' son and successor]] The children of Odaenathus and Zenobia are: *[[Vaballathus]]: he is attested on several coins, inscriptions, and in the ancient literature.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=wnTOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 10|year= 2008}} *[[Harian II]]: his image appear on a seal impression along with his older brother Vaballathus as the sons of Zenobia; his identity is much debated. Potter suggest that he is the same as Herodianus who was crowned in 263 and that Hairan I mentioned in 251 died before the birth of Hairan II.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=hGuGAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT585|title= The Roman Empire at Bay, AD 180–395|author= David S Potter|page= 628|year= 2014}} *Herennianus and Timolaus: the two were mentioned in the Augustan History and are not attested in any other source; Herennianus might be a conflation of Hairan and Herodianus while Timolaus is most probably a fabrication, although [[Dietmar Kienast]] suggest that he might be Vaballathus.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC&pg=PA174|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra s Rebel Queen|author=Pat Southern|page= 174|year= 2008}} Possible descendants of Odaenathus living in later centuries are reported; "Lucia Septimia Patabiniana Balbilla Tyria Nepotilla Odaenathiana" is known through a dedication dating to the late third or early fourth century inscribed on a tombstone erected by a wet nurse to her "sweetest and most loving mistress".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=8kLFfE1qPhIC&pg=PA187|title=Palmyra and Its Empire: Zenobia's Revolt Against Rome|author=Richard Stoneman|page= 187|year= 1994}} The tombstone was found in Rome at the [[San Callisto]] in [[Trastevere]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=DvrQAAAAMAAJ&q|title=Wanderings in the Roman campagna|author=Rodolfo Amedeo Lanciani|page= 169|year= 1909}} Another possible relative is "Eusebius" who is mentioned by [[Libanius]] in 391 as a son of an "Odaenathus" who was in turn a descendant from the king;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tgCKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA110|title= The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars AD 226-363: A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 110|year= 2002}} the father of Eusebius is mentioned as fighting against the Persians (most probably in the ranks of emperor [[Julian (emperor)|Julian]]).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA415|title= Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|language= de|page= 415|year= 2001}} In 393, Libanius mentioned that Eusebius promised him a speech written by [[Cassius Longinus (philosopher)|Longinus]] for the king. In the fifth century, the philosopher "Syrian Odaenathus" lived in [[Athens]] and was a student of [[Plutarch of Athens]];{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=E82oRzHYLhMC&pg=PA199|title=The Philosophers of the Ancient World: An A-Z Guide|author= Trevor Curnow|page= 199|year= 2006}} he might have been a distant descendant of the king.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=_O1KheDl1HMC&pg=PA47|title=428 AD: An Ordinary Year at the End of the Roman Empire|author=Giusto Traina|page= 47|year= 2011}} '''Succession''': the Augustan History claims that Maeonius was proclaimed emperor for a brief period before being killed by the soldiers. However, no inscriptions or other evidence exist for Maeonius' reign and he was probably killed immediately after assassinating the king.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dlEMAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA321#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=History of the decline and fall of the Roman empire for the use of families and young persons: reprinted from the original text, with the careful omission of all passagers of an irreligious tendency, Volume 1|author1=Edward Gibbon |author2=Thomas Bowdler |page= 321|year= 1826}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0mloAAAAMAAJ&q|title=The Age of the Soldier Emperors: Imperial Rome, A.D. 244-284|author= George C. Brauer|page= 163|year= 1975}} Odaenathus was succeeded by his son, the ten-year-old [[Vaballathus]] under the regency of Zenobia.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xno9AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA299#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Ancient Syria: A Three Thousand Year History|author= Trevor Bryce|page= 299|year= 2014}} Hairan II probably died soon after his father,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8kLFfE1qPhIC&pg=PA115#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Palmyra and Its Empire: Zenobia's Revolt Against Rome|author= Richard Stoneman|page= 115|year= 1994}} as only Vaballathus succeeded to the throne.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=uKBhCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT241|title=The Roman Empire from Severus to Constantine|author= Patricia Southern|page= 241|year= 2015}} ==Legacy== {{rquote|right|''Odaenathus, the mention of whose name alone caused the hearts of the Persians to falter. Everywhere victorious, he liberated the cities and the territories belonging to each of them and made the enemies place their salvation in their prayers rather than in the force of arms.''|Libanius, on the exploits of Odaenathus.}} Odaenathus was the founder of the Palmyrene royal dynasty;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=dBIoBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT152|title=Among the Ruins: Syria Past and Present|author= Christian Sahner|page= 152|year= 2014}} he left Palmyra the premier power in the East,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=E5yCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA163|title=Rome's Eastern Trade: International Commerce and Imperial Policy 31 BC - AD 305|author= Gary K. Young|page= 163|year= 2003}} and his actions laid the foundation of Palmyrene strength which culminated in the establishment of the [[Palmyrene Empire]] in 270. Many writers wrote about deeds of Odaenathus; [[Nicostratus of Trebizond]] probably accompanied the king on his campaigns and wrote a history of that period starting from Philip the Arab and ending shortly before the king's death.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=oZcr7SzzVYYC&pg=PA205|title=A Journey to Palmyra: Collected Essays to Remember Delbert R. Hillers|author1=Delbert R. Hillers |author2=Eleonora Cussini |page= 205|year= 2005}} According to Potter, Nicostratus' account was meant to glorify Odaenathus and demonstrate his superiority over Roman emperors.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=oZcr7SzzVYYC&pg=PA206|title=A Journey to Palmyra: Collected Essays to Remember Delbert R. Hillers|author1=Delbert R. Hillers |author2=Eleonora Cussini |page= 206|year= 2005}} The memory of Odaenathus was highly esteemed in the Roman empire; the Augustan History, written in the fourth century, places Odaenathus among the [[Thirty Tyrants (Roman)|Thirty Tyrants]] (probably because he assumed the title of king).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=V9cwAQAAMAAJ&q|title=History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, Volume 5|author= Edward Gibbon|page= 498|year= 1788}} However, it speaks highly of his role in the Persian war and credit him with saving the empire: "Had not Odaenathus, prince of the Palmyrenes, seized the imperial power after the capture of Valerian when the strength of the Roman state was exhausted, all would have been lost in the East".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=tgCKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA74|title=The Roman Eastern Frontier and the Persian Wars AD 226-363: A Documentary History|author1=Michael H. Dodgeon |author2=Samuel N. C. Lieu |page= 74|year= 2002}} The king was praised by Libanius,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=BdcHK8Ll1jMC&pg=PA200|title=Das palmyrenische Teilreich|author= Udo Hartmann|page= 200|language= de|year= 2001}} and was the subject of a prophecy in the [[Sibyl|Thirteenth Sibylline Oracle]]:{{#tag:ref|The Thirteenth Sibylline Oracle is compiled by an oracle who collected a series of earlier texts in chronological order; it is dated to c. 263.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=7HKFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA229|title=The Roman Empire at Bay, AD 180–395|author= David S Potter|page= 229|year= 2014}}|group=note}} "Then shall come one who was sent by the sun [i.e. Odaenathus], a mighty and fearful lion, breathing much flame. Then he with much shameless daring will destroy ... the greatest beast — venomous, fearful and emitting a great deal of hisses [i.e. Shapur]".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=MDzbX7h3h-gC&pg=PA185|title=The Great Empires of the Ancient World|author= Thomas Harrison|page= 185|year= 2009}} Odaenathus is viewed negatively in Rabbinic sources;{{#tag:ref|He is named "Papa ben Nasor" (Papa son of Nasor) in the sources.|group=note}} his sack of Nehardea mortified the Jews,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=oZcr7SzzVYYC&pg=PA209|title=A Journey to Palmyra: Collected Essays to Remember Delbert R. Hillers|author1=Delbert R. Hillers |author2=Eleonora Cussini |page= 209|year= 2005}} and he was cursed by the [[Babylonian Jews]] and the [[History of the Jews and Judaism in the Land of Israel#Roman era .2864 BCE .E2.80.93 324 CE.29|Jews of Palestine]]. ==Ancestors== {{ahnentafel top|width=100%|Ancestors of Odaenathus of Palmyra}}
